intro: Dryadella aviceps, commonly known as the narrowleaf dryad, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, branched stems and finely divided, lance-shaped leaves. Its small white or pale yellow flowers appear in clusters, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
